chunks.chunk_text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil.And I'm Georgie.So Georgie, I'd like to know if you have any brothers or sisters and if you get on well with them.Yes, I do. I have a sister and we get on very well. We didn't used to but now that we're adults we get on well.Well, in this programme we'll be discussing

one of the closest relationships there is, the connection between sisters. We'll hear from three Irish sisters reuniting on a radio show and from a psychotherapist on some stereotypes about sisterhood. Plus, we'll be learning some useful new vocabulary too. And remember, if you want to read along while you listen, you can find the script for this programme on our website bbclearningenglish.com
is C, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, which is the name for the Finance Minister in the UK.OK, Neil, we'll find out if that's the correct answer later in the programme.
Eileen, what would you say if you were to describe our relationship as sisters?
Eileen thinks she gets on with her sisters.To get on with someone means to like them and have a good relationship with them.

But Nula didn't need to worry what her sisters would say. Vera simply said that Nula marches to her own drum. She does things in her own way, which may be different from how other people do things.It seems Vera, Nula and Eileen have remained close friends as they've grown up. But the relationship between older, middle and younger sisters isn't always so harmonious.
Let's listen to BBC Radio 4's Women's Hour special programme as Nula is joined by psychotherapist Jennifer Gledhill.
Nula discusses stereotypes about siblings, a word that means either brother or sister.

What do you think about these stereotypes, Georgie?Are they true for you and your sister?Well, that's interesting.Jennifer did say that there's no scientific proof.Anyway, it's time now to find out the answer

to your question, Georgie.Yes, and my question was what is Rachel Reeves' government job?And you guessed she was the Chancellor of the Exchequer, which was the correct answer.Well done, Neil.Hurray!Okay, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned in this programme, starting with the phrasal verb get on with someone, meaning to have a good relationship with them.If you put someone on the spot, you cause them embarrassment by forcing them to answer a difficult question at that very moment.

If you march to your own drum, you do things in your own unique way, regardless of how other people do them.A sibling can mean either a brother or sister.People who are bossy enjoy telling other people what to do.And finally, a spoiled child is allowed to do whatever they want, becoming badly behaved as a result.

Thanks for listening to 6 Minute English.Did you know we have a BBC Learning English email newsletter?Subscribe for our latest lessons, worksheets and quizzes and weekly tips to help you study.Just search BBC Learning English newsletter or follow the link in the notes for
